events.originalText: Two earthquakes struck northern Afghanistan, triggering a massive landslide that buried a village and killed 75 people.
events.subtitle: 2012 Afghanistan earthquakes
events.headline: Massive landslide in northern Afghanistan kills 75 people

events.originalText: Canadian prime minister Stephen Harper apologised to the First Nations for past governments' policies of forced assimilation.
events.subtitle: Stephen Harper
events.headline: Canadian PM Harper apologises to First Nations for forced assimilation policies

events.originalText: Mudslides caused by heavy monsoon rainfall and exacerbated by hill cutting killed at least 128 people in Chittagong, Bangladesh.
events.subtitle: 2007 Chittagong mudslides
events.headline: Mudslides in Chittagong, Bangladesh kill at least 128 people

events.originalText: Timothy McVeigh, detonator of a truck bomb in front of the Oklahoma federal building, was executed by lethal injection for using a weapon of mass destruction, among other charges.
events.subtitle: Timothy McVeigh
events.headline: Timothy McVeigh executed for Oklahoma federal building bombing

events.originalText: Robert Edward Dyer was sentenced to 16 years' imprisonment for conducting a six-month-long letter-bomb campaign against the British supermarket chain Tesco.
events.subtitle: Tesco bomb campaign
events.headline: Robert Edward Dyer sentenced to 16 years for letter-bomb campaign against Tesco

events.originalText: In one of the most famous upsets in FA Cup history, Sutton United, a team in the fifth tier of English league football, defeated top-tier Coventry City.
events.subtitle: FA Cup
events.headline: Sutton United upsets Coventry City in FA Cup

events.originalText: Steven Spielberg's E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial was released, and went on to set the record for the highest-grossing film of all time, which it held for 11 years.
events.subtitle: Steven Spielberg
events.headline: Steven Spielberg's E.T. released, becomes highest-grossing film

events.originalText: The University of Alabama was desegregated as Governor George Wallace stepped aside after defiantly blocking the entrance to an auditorium.
events.subtitle: University of Alabama
events.headline: University of Alabama desegregated as Governor Wallace steps aside

events.originalText: Vietnamese monk Thích Quảng Đức burned himself to death in Saigon to protest the persecution of Buddhists by Catholic South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem's administration.
events.subtitle: Bhikkhu
events.headline: Vietnamese monk Thích Quảng Đức self-immolates in protest

events.originalText: American criminals Clarence Anglin, John Anglin and Frank Morris escaped from Alcatraz Island, one of the United States' most famous prisons.
events.subtitle: June 1962 Alcatraz escape attempt
events.headline: Alcatraz escapees Clarence Anglin, John Anglin, and Frank Morris

events.originalText: Kitosh, an African labourer, died after having been flogged by his British employer, in a case that eventually led to reform of the legal system of the Kenya Colony.
events.subtitle: Jasper Abraham murder case
events.headline: African labourer Kitosh dies after flogging by British employer

events.originalText: During their national convention in Chicago, Republican Party leaders gathered in negotiations at The Blackstone Hotel to select their presidential candidate, leading to the phrase "smoke-filled room".
events.subtitle: 1920 Republican National Convention
events.headline: Republican Party leaders negotiate at The Blackstone Hotel for presidential candidate

events.originalText: Alexander (pictured) was crowned King of Greece, succeeding his father Constantine I, who had abdicated.
events.subtitle: Alexander of Greece
events.headline: Alexander crowned King of Greece, succeeding Constantine I

events.originalText: Around 2,000 members of European society attended a ball at Kenwood House, England, in one of the last major social events before the outbreak of the First World War.
events.subtitle: 1914 Kenwood House ball
events.headline: 2,000 attend ball at Kenwood House before outbreak of First World War

events.originalText: Prince Afonso (pictured) died at the age of two, leaving his father Pedro II, the last emperor of Brazil, without a male heir.
events.subtitle: Afonso, Prince Imperial of Brazil
events.headline: Prince Afonso dies, leaving Pedro II without male heir

events.originalText: Tensions between Yankees and Irish Americans in Boston, Massachusetts, erupted in the Broad Street Riot.
events.subtitle: Yankee
events.headline: Broad Street Riot erupts between Yankees and Irish Americans in Boston

events.originalText: The Battle of Machias, the first naval engagement of the American Revolutionary War, commenced in and around the port of Machias in what is now eastern Maine.
events.subtitle: Battle of Machias
events.headline: Battle of Machias, first naval engagement of American Revolutionary War, commences

events.originalText: Philip II of Spain recognized the sovereign rights of the principalía, the local nobles and chieftains of the Philippines who had converted to Catholicism.
events.subtitle: Philip II of Spain
events.headline: Philip II of Spain recognizes sovereign rights of principalía in the Philippines

events.originalText: Catherine of Aragon (pictured) married King Henry VIII of England, becoming the first of his six wives.
events.subtitle: Catherine of Aragon
events.headline: Catherine of Aragon marries King Henry VIII of England

events.originalText: Inspecting a new prison without being escorted by his bodyguard, the megas doux Alexios Apokaukos, chief minister of the Byzantine Empire, was lynched by the prisoners.
events.subtitle: Megas doux
events.headline: Chief minister of Byzantine Empire lynched by prisoners during prison inspection

events.originalText: Arab–Byzantine wars: The Abbasid army departed Raqqa in northern Syria to begin an invasion of Byzantine-controlled Asia Minor.
events.subtitle: Arab–Byzantine wars
events.headline: Abbasid army invades Byzantine-controlled Asia Minor after departing Raqqa
